Why?

The point of all of this is to answer the question: what do n-bit binary integers have to do with polynomials and why is relating those things to each other at all useful? Read on to find out!

Rings and Ideals

If R is a commutative ring, a subset I of R is an ideal if it is

  • closed under addition and multiplication
  • has the â€œabsorptionâ€ property: anything in R times anything in I lands back in I.

The ideal generated by a subset Sâ€„âŠ†â€„R is the set of all sums of eleemnts of S multiplied by elements of R. A very nice kind of ideal is an ideal generated by a set with one element: if Sâ€„=â€„{s}, this ideal is written simply as (s). An ideal generated by a single element is called a principal ideal.

Ideals are the subsets of rings we can â€œmod outâ€ by, that is, out of which we can form quotient rings: if I is an ideal, we consider elements of R to be equivalent if their difference is in I, then define addition and multiplication on the set R/I of equivalence classes in terms of the corresponding operations on R. Ideals have nice properties that make this work.

Modular arithmetic

Fields

A field is basically a ring in which every element has an additive inverse and every non-zero element has a multiplicative inverse. So we can add, multiply, subtract, and divide. Fields can be finite or infinite. If p is a prime, then â„¤/pâ„¤ is a field. â„¤/pnâ„¤, however, is not a field: in this ring, it is possible to multiply together two non-zero numbers, e.g.Â p and pnâ€…âˆ’â€…1, and get zero. It follows from the definition of a field that, in a field, this never happens. (Fields are integral domains.)

The Standard Trick

There is a general trick that if S is a set and C is some cool algebraic thing like a group, ring, vector space, field, whatever, and we have a bijection of sets Ï•â€„:â€„Sâ€„â†’â€„C, then we can make S into a cool algebraic thing by â€œpulling backâ€ the operations on C: to perform operations on a pair, say, of elements of S we just send them over to C, operate there, then send the result back and define that to be how operations on S work. So that is what is happening here: we have some operations on arrays of bits of size n, but not all the ones we want. We do, however, have a bijection to this fancy polynomial ring where multiplication is really niceâ€”it is a field so everything has a multiplicative inverseâ€”so we can just define a new multiplication on arrays of bits by sending them over there, multiplying there, and sending the answer back.
